Posts.Content: I hope your girlfriend decides to go ahead with science-based medicine. Since she is still early stage it seems likely that she could receive treatment and be in the clear for a very long time. She's still very young, to be using treatments with no (scientifically) proven advantages seems like an unnecessary risk. Good luck to you both.
Posts.Signature: Kirsten. Boyfriend Rio diagnosed NSHL 29th July 2014 (24 years old) Stage IVBSX (~15 cm primary tumour) eBEACOPP 30th July to 3rd December, 2014 Post TX PET 12th January, 2015 Results 20th January, 2015 Complete metabolic response. Rio's remission has begun!

Posts.Title: Conventional Treatment vs. Complimentary

Posts.Content: Hi, I don't know much about breast cancer but from the looks of it, if there were "traces" of disease in a lymph node, it could be why she is receiving chemo. If there was disease found in a lymph node, it would mean that all the cancer was not removed. I'm not sure what "traces" really means though - I've never heard that terminology applied to potential lymph node involvement. I believe with most cancers that can be treated (or mostly treated) through surgery need at least a few weeks for recovery. Chemo is hard on the body and reduces the ability to fight infection, so they probably want a good amount of healing done before they would consider exposing a patient to potential infection risks. Good luck to your aunt, I hope her treatment is successful and that it isn't too hard on her.
